text:
Hello,

I am a fan of learning from other countries. I looked into Singapore but I think it may be more helpful to look at other African countries with similar infrastructure and cultural norms.

Here is an article that talks about how Nigeria handled Ebola. Very impressive and effective ideas we could adapt.

<https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-did-nigeria-quash-its-ebola-outbreak-so-quickly/>

attachments.title: How Did Nigeria Quash Its Ebola Outbreak So Quickly?
attachments.text: What we can learn from the boot leather, organization and quick response times that stopped Ebola from spreading in this African nation
attachments.fallback: Scientific American: How Did Nigeria Quash Its Ebola Outbreak So Quickly?

text: <#CVCEGMQ8H|projects-list>

These drives show people washing their hands but everyone is turning tap before and after cleaning. There needs to be some notification to avoid touching public surfaces like the heads of taps as that could be a contaminant.

text:
China and Korea used phone app such as FluPhone that used Bluetooth & other wireless signals proxy for interactions between people and asked users to report flu-like symptoms.
If you’d had lunch with someone who later got sick, FluPhone would let you know. Besides slowing the spread of the flu, the app promised to help health authorities monitor and model the spread of influenza. FluPhone made headlines and the front page of the BBC website at the time. 

<https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.wired.com/story/phones-track-spread-covid19-good-idea/amp|https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.wired.com/story/phones-track-spread-covid19-good-idea/amp>

attachments.title: Phones Could Track the Spread of Covid-19. Is It a Good Idea?
attachments.text: China and South Korea used smartphone apps to monitor people with the disease. But Americans have different views of privacy and data collection.
attachments.fallback: Wired: Phones Could Track the Spread of Covid-19. Is It a Good Idea?

elements.text: China and Korea used phone app such as FluPhone that used Bluetooth & other wireless signals proxy for interactions between people and asked users to report flu-like symptoms.

If you’d had lunch with someone who later got sick, FluPhone would let you know. Besides slowing the spread of the flu, the app promised to help health authorities monitor and model the spread of influenza. FluPhone made headlines and the front page of the BBC website at the time.
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.wired.com/story/phones-track-spread-covid19-good-idea/amp

text: Hi guys, one of the biggest issues I've noticed (especially with my family) is communicating to them the value of social distancing. Are there any channels that are meant for creating campaigns for raising awareness and communicating best practices?

elements.text: Hi guys, one of the biggest issues I've noticed (especially with my family) is communicating to them the value of social distancing. Are there any channels that are meant for creating campaigns for raising awareness and communicating best practices?

text:
I totally agree with this. There are a few obstacles:

1. People do not believe/understand the magnitude of the issue.
2. People want to congregate to chat/pray when things unusual happen.
3. A lot of people are not tech savvy and may just not know the details. 
I agree that some sort of campaign - it will need to be creative - for our people, for this issue - to communicate what needs to be done.

elements.text: I totally agree with this. There are a few obstacles:

People want to congregate to chat/pray when things unusual happen.
A lot of people are not tech savvy and may just not know the details.
I agree that some sort of campaign - it will need to be creative - for our people, for this issue - to communicate what needs to be done.

text:
I agree with y’all said, the other issue is attending religious services is really meaningful to our community. Religious leaders have a big role to think through all the parts of their services and identify all of the times when people come in contact either with each other or with a shared common service, and then try to decide whether those moments can either be removed from the service or whether there is another meaningful, comfortable replacement that could stand in for till the virus get under control. So in many houses of worship of all faiths, handshakes should be recommended to replaced with alternatives like waves or elbow bumps. People must advise not to shake hands after prayer, as many commonly do, and leaders have to guid the community of telling  if they are sick, they are exempted from obligations to attend daily prayers and/or Sunday sermons.

Below CDC Interim guidance to help community and faith based organizations: 

<https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/guidance-community-faith-organizations.html|https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/guidance-community-faith-organizations.html>

attachments.service_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
attachments.title: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) - Get Your Community- and Faith-Based Organizations Ready for Coronavirus Disease 2019
attachments.text: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) - Get Your Community- and Faith-Based Organizations Ready for Coronavirus Disease 2019
attachments.fallback: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) - Get Your Community- and Faith-Based Organizations Ready for Coronavirus Disease 2019

Religious leaders have a big role to think through all the parts of their services and identify all of the times when people come in contact either with each other or with a shared common service, and then try to decide whether those moments can either be removed from the service or whether there is another meaningful, comfortable replacement that could stand in for till the virus get under control. So in many houses of worship of all faiths, handshakes should be recommended to replaced with alternatives like waves or elbow bumps. People must advise not to shake hands after prayer, as many commonly do, and leaders have to guid the community of telling  if they are sick, they are exempted from obligations to attend daily prayers and/or Sunday sermons.

attachments.title: Security Alert: Reports of Anti-Foreigner Sentiment | U.S. Embassy in Ethiopia
attachments.text: LOCATION:  Ethiopia EVENT:  The Embassy continues to receive reports regarding a rise in anti-foreigner sentiment revolving around the announcement of COVID-19 in Ethiopia. Typical derogatory comments directed at foreigners, the terms “China” and “Ferengi” (foreigner), have been reportedly coupled with the label “Corona,” indicating a disparaging view on the link between the outbreak of COVID-19 and ...

text:
Idea:
While developing the app can we add location (latitude and longitude) of the suspected person. So that we can calculate/know our distance from the person and act accordingly.
